review.title: Reasoning over Ontologies with Hidden Content: The Import-by-Query Approach
review.abstract: There is currently a growing interest in techniques for hiding parts of the signature of an ontology Kh that is being reused by another ontology Kv. Towards this goal, in this paper we propose the import-by-query framework, which makes the content of Kh accessible through a limited query interface. If Kv reuses the symbols from Kh in a certain restricted way, one can reason over Kv U Kh by accessing only Kv and the query interface. We map out the landscape of the import-by-query problem. In particular, we outline the limitations of our framework and prove that certain restrictions on the expressivity of Kh and the way in which Kv reuses symbols from Kh are strictly necessary to enable reasoning in our setting. We also identify cases in which reasoning is possible and we present suitable import-by-query reasoning algorithms.

If Kv reuses the symbols of Kh in a certain limited way, one can argue about Kv-Kh by accessing only Kv and the query interface. We design the landscape of the import-by-query problem. In particular, we outline the limitations of our framework and demonstrate that certain limitations of the expressivity of Kh and the way in which Kv reuses symbols of Kh are absolutely necessary to allow reasoning in our setting. We also identify cases in which reasoning is possible and present appropriate import-by-query reasoning algorithms.

sections.heading: 8. Conclusion
sections.text: Our findings provide a flexible way for ontology developers to ensure selective access to their ontologies. Thus, our framework provides important theoretical insights into privacy issues in ontology. Furthermore, we believe that our algorithms are practicable when applied to Horn's ontologies; therefore, our findings provide a starting point for the development of practical import query systems. The problem of import-by-query is new and we see many open questions. One problem that is relevant both in theory and practice, for example, is allowing hidden ontology to export data selectively, rather than just schema statements.
